description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description:
Starting on August 21, 2020, in all secondary school buildings, social distancing of 1 meter between individuals should be applied. In situations where the principle of intimacy cannot be enforced, such as practical teaching, art education and clinical learning, a face mask covering the mouth and nose should be worn. Both teachers and students should wear a mask. Educational processes shall be organized so that each student interacts with as few as possible. Students should be distributed to permanent entrances to a school building as far as possible and corridors shall be a travel space. Permanent groups and classes should be avoided as far as possible mixing with other students. All non-teaching events should be cancelled. 
Common equipment/contact surfaces should be disinfected at least once a day and emphasis should also be placed on individual antiseptic measures.

Preschool administration may require parents to wear face masks. Non-employees and parents entering kindergartens, such as for freight, care should be taken to a 2-metre proximity restriction. description:
On October 19, 2020, the general regulations about social gatherings remain the same, the maximum number of people is 30, born in 2004 or earlier. Primary schools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. This regulations are applied to after school centres, community centres and sports activities in primary schools. Parents and relatives are not allowed to enter school buildings except when absolutely necessary. Disinfection should be taken after each day. UPDATE: On November 02, 2020, new regulations for several levels of junior schools.
First level, i.e. Grades 1–4: Pupils are exempted from the 2-metre social distancing rule and are not required to wear face masks. Social gathering limit is 50 people. The same rules apply for after-school leisure centres for children in Grades 1-4.
Grades 5–10: Social gathering limit is 25 pupils. The social distancing rule of 2-metres should be kept. In case the distance rule can not be kept, face masks should be worn. Staff must also observe the distance rule and use face masks when it is needed.
Group mixing of pupils are not allowed, the same group divisions shall be observed among pupils in junior schools and in after-school leisure centres, so ensuring that there is no mixing between pupil groups. The rules on group sizes and mixing of groups may be set aside in common areas in schools, providing that pupils in Grades 5–10, and the staff, wear face masks. Staff are permitted to move between groups and limit of gathering is 10 people. Staff needs to keep distance rule of 2 metres. Social events, sport activities are prohibited.

description:
Iceland Minister of Health announced new regulations on the restrictions of school activities due to infection prevention measures. The policy will take effect from March 25, 2021 and shall remain in force up to 31 March 2021. Preschools may maintain school work in school buildings with a 2-metre proximity limit between staff. Whenever the social distance of 2 metres cannot be ensured, masks shouls be worn. Employees are not obliged to wear face masks when communicating with preschoolers. There should be no more than 10 adults in each space. Children are exempt from mass gathering and social distancing limitations. Parents are not allowed to enter the building without necessity. Adaptation periods should be organized in a way that parents do not need to use sanitation or food facilities in the building and keep at least a 2-metre proximity restriction both between themselves and towards staff. Only one parent accompanies the child in an adjustment.
Preschool administrators may require parents to wear face masks. Non-employees entering kindergartens (i.e. service staff, freight) should keep 2-metre proximity restriction and wear face masks.

description:
In Iceland, from July 13th, for Icelandic residents and citizens returning home have to on arrival complete a period of “heimkomusmitgát” (home-coming contagion caution). This means will they be tested for COVID-19 at the border and they will also be required to undergo a second free PCR test at a local healthcare centre four to five days later. Until they get the results of the second test Icelanders should:

Maintain two-metre distancing
Only attend gatherings of up to ten people
Avoid high-risk individuals e.g. the elderly
Avoid physical contact

Heimkomusmitgát is not the same as quarantine; Icelanders will be  permitted to use public transport, go to shops and meet family and friends whilst they await test results.

In pre-schools and junior schools up to 20 staff may occupy the same area, and may move between groups. These rules will also apply to after-school activity centres, organised sports events, youth activities and leisure activities, and to the operations of social centres. In upper-secondary schools gathering ban is up to 30 pupils and staff may occupy the same area. Pupils may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. In universities gathering ban is up to 50 students and staff may occupy each teaching or study area. Mixing between these groups of students will not be permitted, though staff may move between groups. Whenever the distance rule can not be kept, fase masks shuld be used. Music lessons for children in pre-schools and junior school are permitted, observing the same rules as apply to each school level respectively. For older pupils, the same restrictions will apply to music lessons as to upper-secondary schools.

description:
Iceland Minister of Health announced new regulations on the restrictions of school activities due to infection prevention measures. The policy will take effect from March 25, 2021 and shall remain in force up to 31 March 2021. Preschools may maintain school work in school buildings with a 2-metre proximity limit between staff. Whenever the social distance of 2 metres cannot be ensured, masks shouls be worn. Employees are not obliged to wear face masks when communicating with preschoolers. There should be no more than 10 adults in each space. Children are exempt from mass gathering and social distancing limitations. Parents are not allowed to enter the building without necessity. Adaptation periods should be organized in a way that parents do not need to use sanitation or food facilities in the building and keep at least a 2-metre proximity restriction both between themselves and towards staff. Only one parent accompanies the child in an adjustment.
Preschool administrators may require parents to wear face masks. Non-employees entering kindergartens (i.e. service staff, freight) should keep 2-metre proximity restriction and wear face masks.

The Minister of Health, the Ministry of Education, Science and Culture on March 31, 2021 announced regulations regarding the operation of schools. Starting from April 1 through April 15, the following regulations in kindergartens are applied:
Children are exempt from gathering and social distancing rules. The maximum number of adults is limited to 20 and staff are allowed to move between spaces. Staff should keep the social distancing rule of 2 metres. Whenever this rule cannot be kept, masks should be worn. Events are permitted in the school work with the participation of students and staff but no outsiders.
Parents and relatives shall not enter school buildings unless clearly necessary and shall wear a face mask.
